content: Well, they're email messages, not documents. What you want can be done, but it's work. What you might want to pursue will be separate process, converting eml messages to pdf or doc format. A simple web search for 'eml to doc' or 'eml to pdf' will show many products, none of which we have tested or can comment on. If you pursue this direction, the addon, importexporttools, can readily export messages to eml for you. Then, you would have just a few steps: export to eml, execute the third-party product, and you would then have all of your messsages in your preferred format. Good luck .

content:
First, let's clear your setup. you appear to have two accounts, one for info and one for elainemarie. Please do the following so we have a clear view of your status:

  1. click to the SMTP server pane, and click Edit for each one and Change DESCRIPTION field for each to be unique, such as the email address for that smtp server. Currently, i think they both have same description,
  2. now, click 'account settings' and look at account pane bottom line where it links to an SMTP server. Adjust to apply to the correct one.
  3. now, try sending email from each one and then report error message.

The above steps to to ensure that the SMTP server for info is the one used by the info account and the one for elainemarie is using its specific SMTP server. My concern was heightened when your first screenshot was for info and your second for elainemarie. The changes I recommended may not be the solution, but will at minimum give us proper messages.

Sorry, but No. Thunderbird is a free product. It relies on donations to maintain code, security etc. There are no people managing phones. People live all over the world and helpers live all over the world.

creator: elainemariearriola

content:
I notice this..it is asking for 'password' in the error pop up. You have set up account to use Authentication Method: Oauth2.

That means gmail account should be using an access oauth token and gmail server will be expecting that token, so it will never accept the normal password.

When you set up the pop account did you get pop up to logon to google with password and then get another window where you had to click on 'Allow to let Thunderbird access google server ?

Are you using Thunderbird version 128.2.3esr ? If no then pleases update.

Please check you have the following set up:

  • In Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Web Content:
  • Select 'Accept cookies from sites'
  • Accept third party cookies: 'Always
  • Click on 'Exceptions' button
  • Add this: https://accounts.google.com
  • Set it to 'Allow'
  • click on 'Save Changes'

Confirm you have set up as above.

content:
Ok based on your third image it looks like you installed Language Packs and not Dictionaries. In the first image it says download more dictionaries in the spelling section.

The spell checker in Thunderbird and Firefox uses dictionaries as the Language Packs is a way to have one install but be able to change the language of the user interface like the menus and such to another language.

https://addons.thunderbird.net/thunderbird/language-tools/

Installing a dictionary add-on will add a new language option to your Thunderbird spell-checker, which checks your spelling when you fill out Web forms. Language pack add-ons change the language of the entire application.

A similar message is on top of https://addons.mozilla.org/firefox/language-tools/ for Firefox.
creator: James

content:
Hello James,

As the saying goes, a picture is worth a thousand words, in any language. Replacing the French language pack with the dictionary has given me the option to change to French in the "Spelling" pull down.

That only leaves me wondering why Grammalecte didn't work. I initially installed that following a Mozilla extension recommendation, mainly because I've been impressed by it in Libreoffice for many years.

Nonetheless I have a working solution.

Thank you
creator: palmerconsultingfr

content:
And I've now solved the Grammalecte issue.

Regarding my first action of installing Grammalecte, that appeared to do nothing for the spell check function, I now have found the answer. Opening a wider new message window reveals to button "Analyser", which invokes the Grammalecte spell checker.

You need to keep all responses in the original question otherwise the conversation gets broken https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1465127

creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re : I received your response on my cell phone and tried to respond

If you are reading an email because someone posted a comment in a question you created, then you cannot 'Reply'. When a comment gets posted - the server sends email - it's not a direct email from the person posting the comment.

You will find a link within the email content itself:

There's a button that says something like 'Mark it as solved' which you can use if the info solves the problem.

Next to that button is some text that says 'This doesn't solve my problem' - click on that text link and it should auto open the browser and Support forum and focus on your question.
creator: Toad-Hall

creator: elise6

content:
The usual way of Deleting a folder - is right click on folder and select 'Delete'. But apparently that is failing.

Image shows they are ordinary folders so that tell me the flag settings are ok.

As they are IMAP folders, then try the following to get around this issue.

In Folder Pane

  • Right click on the actual imap mail account name folder and select 'Subscribe'
  • Select the names of all the folders you want to remove and then click on 'Unsubscribe'
  • Click on 'OK'

Then collapse and expand the imap account by clicking on the > chevron displayed on the left of the account name.

This should refresh it.

This should mean you cannot see those folders in Thunderbird, but they would still be on the server. To remove them from server - logon to webmail account via a browser.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Thank you so much, I was able to delete the folders.

Please excuse what may seem like a stupid question: How do I logon to webmail account - am I assuming correctly that you mean the Thunderbird webmail?

I've become a little bit less tech savvy as I grow older.
creator: elise6

content:
Thunderbird is just a program running on your computer. It enables you to download emails to your computer so you can read them and send emails etc. So in Thunderbird you have a 'mail account' which is specific for your email address.

The webmail account is the main access to see your account details and your emails. You do this in a browser such as 'Mozilla Firefox'. Internet Service Providers have their own websites and you logon to see your account details.

It depends upon the following: Are you using an email address provided by your internet service provider? Or a free one such as gmail ? What comes after the '@' in your email address?
